messages.message: prepending `/` wasn’t actually the solution here. problem was caused by trying to read the image while the write was in progress (so the previously written image wasn’t accessible). changing the code to do converted image writes before proceeding fixed the problem.

Yep that makes sense — this is what i was referring to here in this comment above: “so these jpeg typically get written async — so you might want to check to see whether this file is truly being written asynchronously or synchronously”

all good :slightly_smiling_face: i’ll try to communicate that more clearly
aah yup — you were correct in the end. I incorrect assumed that the write operation (if in progress) wouldn’t hinder reading the already-existing file of the same name.
